questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL :SOFTWARE ENGINEERING" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1: A software company has developed a mobile app that can be used to book hotel rooms. The app is available to download and install. The company provides upgrades for the app from time to time. What phase of the software development process is the app in right now?
question_texts: A software company has developed a mobile app that can be used to book hotel rooms. The app is available to download and install. The company provides upgrades for the app from time to time. What phase of the software development process is the app in right now?

questions.question_text_1: In a software development process, all the phases take place sequentially, and the users get their first view of the developed software during or after the testing phase. Identify the type of software development model followed here.
question_texts: In a software development process, all the phases take place sequentially, and the users get their first view of the developed software during or after the testing phase. Identify the type of software development model followed here.

questions.question_text_1: Consider an online flower store where users can place an order to send flower bouquets. The customers can select from a range of bouquets and place an order. Once the order is placed the store manager makes a phone call to the courier service provider to pick up the ordered item from the physical store and arrange the delivery.  Identify the most appropriate user type for the courier service provider
question_texts: Consider an online flower store where users can place an order to send flower bouquets. The customers can select from a range of bouquets and place an order. Once the order is placed the store manager makes a phone call to the courier service provider to pick up the ordered item from the physical store and arrange the delivery.  Identify the most appropriate user type for the courier service provider

questions.question_text_1: An organisation has planned to develop an online pet store app that would allow its customers to buy and sell different pet animals on this common platform. The organisation goes through several documents regarding pet shop rules and the duties and obligations of the pet shop owners as part of their requirements gathering.  What kind of requirement-gathering technique is used in the given scenario?
question_texts: An organisation has planned to develop an online pet store app that would allow its customers to buy and sell different pet animals on this common platform. The organisation goes through several documents regarding pet shop rules and the duties and obligations of the pet shop owners as part of their requirements gathering.  What kind of requirement-gathering technique is used in the given scenario?

questions.question_text_1: Consider that for a software project, the requirements are collected as user stories. After the creation of the user stories, it was found that the implementation of some of the user stories was not possible with a single agile iteration. Therefore, those user stories are subdivided into smaller user stories. This process makes the user stories _________.  Fill in the blank with the appropriate option.
question_texts: Consider that for a software project, the requirements are collected as user stories. After the creation of the user stories, it was found that the implementation of some of the user stories was not possible with a single agile iteration. Therefore, those user stories are subdivided into smaller user stories. This process makes the user stories _________.  Fill in the blank with the appropriate option.

questions.question_text_1: Consider an image processing software that can enhance an old image and can also convert a black-and-white image to a coloured one. After installing the software, it prompts its user to take a tour that guides the user in a step-by-step way to understand how to use the software. Which of the following usability goals is fulfilled by the software discussed above?
question_texts: Consider an image processing software that can enhance an old image and can also convert a black-and-white image to a coloured one. After installing the software, it prompts its user to take a tour that guides the user in a step-by-step way to understand how to use the software. Which of the following usability goals is fulfilled by the software discussed above?

questions.question_text_1: Consider a food delivery app provided by a renowned chain of restaurants. The customers can explore the menu without signing up for the app. However, when he or she finally attempts to place the order, he or she needs to sign in to the app.  Which of the following heuristics of UI evaluation is fulfilled in this case?
question_texts: Consider a food delivery app provided by a renowned chain of restaurants. The customers can explore the menu without signing up for the app. However, when he or she finally attempts to place the order, he or she needs to sign in to the app.  Which of the following heuristics of UI evaluation is fulfilled in this case?

questions.question_text_1: What is product backlog from the agile perspective?
question_texts: What is product backlog from the agile perspective?

options.option_text: Short, time-boxed period when a scrum team works to complete a set amountof work.
Prioritized list of tasks for the development team, derived from the user storiesand requirements.
List of user stories/tasks, that went well or that didn't go well.
List of tasks completed by the development team, and the tasks moved fromthe To-Do/In-Progress to Completed.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about Storyboards?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about Storyboards?

options.option_text: Storyboards are prototypes that are in the form of a hand-drawn comicfeaturing the setting, sequence, and satisfaction.
Storyboards are presented on multiple papers as hand-drawn UIs of differentscreens
Storyboards emphasise on how the interface accomplishes a task; however,avoid commitment to a particular user interface
Storyboards are web apps created using fake data

questions.question_text_1: A software company is developing a website for a school that can be used by the teachers to upload their notes and video lectures from time to time so that students can access them from anywhere. However, the team from the software company responsible for gathering requirements was not able to capture the actual requirements of the school. As a result, the development team created some incorrect functions that did not meet the needs of the client.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: A software company is developing a website for a school that can be used by the teachers to upload their notes and video lectures from time to time so that students can access them from anywhere. However, the team from the software company responsible for gathering requirements was not able to capture the actual requirements of the school. As a result, the development team created some incorrect functions that did not meet the needs of the client.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Consider that for a given project, the probability of schedule slippage is 30% and the impact due to schedule slippage is measured as 3. What will be the risk associated with schedule slippage for the given project?
question_texts: Consider that for a given project, the probability of schedule slippage is 30% and the impact due to schedule slippage is measured as 3. What will be the risk associated with schedule slippage for the given project?

questions.question_text_1: A set of modules is said to have high cohesion and low coupling, which implies _____________.
question_texts: A set of modules is said to have high cohesion and low coupling, which implies _____________.

options.option_text: The functions in each module are performing varied operations, and a lot ofdata interchanged between the modules.
The functions in each module are together performing a single operation, anda lot of data is interchanged between the modules.
The functions in each module are together performing a single operation, andthe degree of interaction between the modules is very low.

questions.question_text_1: During debugging a system, the developer finds out an event that triggers an incorrect behaviour. He follows the data control flow ahead until the incorrect state is reached.  Which of the following debugging strategies was chosen by the developer?
question_texts: During debugging a system, the developer finds out an event that triggers an incorrect behaviour. He follows the data control flow ahead until the incorrect state is reached.  Which of the following debugging strategies was chosen by the developer?

questions.question_text_1: Consider a data processing software that is made of several data filters. The filters are connected one after another. Each filter processes the data it receives and sends the output to the next filter in line. Which type of architecture is used to design the data processing software?
question_texts: Consider a data processing software that is made of several data filters. The filters are connected one after another. Each filter processes the data it receives and sends the output to the next filter in line. Which type of architecture is used to design the data processing software?

questions.question_text_1: A software company is developing inventory management software for a medicine distributor. The software needs to be connected to a third-party module for invoice generation and printing. However, the data format used by the software is not compatible with the third-party module. Therefore, the development team has introduced a new class that converts the data format so that it is supported by the third-party module and has integrated the third-party module with the software. Which kind of design pattern is used in this case?
question_texts: A software company is developing inventory management software for a medicine distributor. The software needs to be connected to a third-party module for invoice generation and printing. However, the data format used by the software is not compatible with the third-party module. Therefore, the development team has introduced a new class that converts the data format so that it is supported by the third-party module and has integrated the third-party module with the software. Which kind of design pattern is used in this case?

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC)
- **Phases**: Requirements gathering, Design, Development, Testing, Maintenance
- **Models**:
  - **Waterfall Model**: Sequential phases, users see the product after testing.
  - **Agile Model**: Iterative development, user stories, product backlog.
  - **Prototype Model**: Early prototypes for user feedback.
  - **Spiral Model**: Iterative development with risk assessment.

#### Requirements Gathering
- **Techniques**: Interviews, Focus groups, Naturalistic observations, Documentation
- **User Stories**: Should be achievable, measurable, relevant, and timeboxed.

#### Usability Goals
- **Learnability**: Ease with which new users can learn to use the software.
- **Effectiveness**: Ability of users to complete tasks.
- **Efficiency**: Speed with which users can complete tasks.
- **Safety**: Protection against errors and misuse.
- **Memorability**: Ease with which users can remember how to use the software.

#### User Types
- **Primary Users**: Direct users of the software.
- **Secondary Users**: Indirect users who interact with the software occasionally.
- **Tertiary Users**: Users affected by the software but do not interact directly.

#### Software Metrics
- **Raw Metrics**: Lines of Code (LOC), Logical Lines of Code (LLOC), Source Lines of Code (SLOC).
- **Cyclomatic Complexity**: Measures the complexity of a program.
- **Halstead’s Metrics**: Measures program complexity based on operators and operands.
- **Code Smell**: Indicators of poor code quality.

#### UML Diagrams
- **Activity Diagram**: Represents workflows of stepwise activities.
- **State Machine View**: Represents states and transitions.
- **Interaction View**: Represents the sequence of messages exchanged between different parts of the system.

#### Risk Management
- **Technical Risk**: Risks related to the technical aspects of the project.
- **Project Risks**: Risks related to project management.
- **Business Risk**: Risks related to business aspects.
- **Risk Calculation**: Risk = Probability of occurrence * Impact.

#### COCOMO Model
- **Equation**: Effort = a * (KLOC)^b * EAF
  - **Organic Project**: a = 2.4, b = 1.05
  - **Semi-detached Project**: a = 3.0, b = 1.12
  - **Embedded Project**: a = 3.6, b = 1.20
  - **EAF**: Effort Adjustment Factor

#### Design Patterns
- **Adapter Design Pattern**: Converts the interface of a class into another interface clients expect.
- **Facade Design Pattern**: Provides a simplified interface to a complex subsystem.
- **Builder Design Pattern**: Separates the construction of a complex object from its representation.
- **Strategy Design Pattern**: Defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable.

#### Debugging
- **Error**: Discrepancy between actual behavior and intended behavior.
- **Failure**: Observable errors like incorrect output value, exception, etc.
- **Fault**: Where the failure has occurred.
- **Debugging**: Determining the cause of failure.
- **Debugging Strategies**:
  - **Forwards Strategy**: Follow the data control flow ahead until the incorrect state is reached.
  - **Backwards Strategy**: Work backward from the point of failure to find the cause.

#### Software Architecture
- **Client-Server**: Separates the client and server roles.
- **Pipe and Filter**: Connects filters where the output of one is the input to the next.
- **Model-View-Controller (MVC)**: Separates the application into three interconnected components.
- **Peer-to-Peer**: Decentralized architecture where each peer has equal capabilities.

#### SOLID Principles
- **Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)**: A class should have only one reason to change.
- **Open/Closed Principle (OCP)**: Software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.
- **Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)**: Objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of a subclass without affecting the correctness of the program.
- **Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)**: Many client-specific interfaces are better than one general-purpose interface.
- **Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)**: Depend upon abstractions, do not depend upon concretions.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Software Development Life Cycle] --> B[Requirements Gathering]
    A --> C[Design]
    A --> D[Development]
    A --> E[Testing]
    A --> F[Maintenance]
    B --> G[Interviews]
    B --> H[Focus Groups]
    B --> I[Naturalistic Observations]
    B --> J[Documentation]
    C --> K[Waterfall Model]
    C --> L[Agile Model]
    C --> M[Prototype Model]
    C --> N[Spiral Model]
    D --> O[User Stories]
    D --> P[Product Backlog]
    E --> Q[Usability Goals]
    Q --> R[Learnability]
    Q --> S[Effectiveness]
    Q --> T[Efficiency]
    Q --> U[Safety]
    Q --> V[Memorability]
    F --> W[Software Metrics]
    W --> X[Raw Metrics]
    W --> Y[Cyclomatic Complexity]
    W --> Z[Halstead’s Metrics]
    W --> AA[Code Smell]
    A --> AB[UML Diagrams]
    AB --> AC[Activity Diagram]
    AB --> AD[State Machine View]
    AB --> AE[Interaction View]
    A --> AF[Risk Management]
    AF --> AG[Technical Risk]
    AF --> AH[Project Risks]
    AF --> AI[Business Risk]
    AF --> AJ[Risk Calculation]
    A --> AK[COCOMO Model]
    AK --> AL[Organic Project]
    AK --> AM[Semi-detached Project]
    AK --> AN[Embedded Project]
    A --> AO[Design Patterns]
    AO --> AP[Adapter Design Pattern]
    AO --> AQ[Facade Design Pattern]
    AO --> AR[Builder Design Pattern]
    AO --> AS[Strategy Design Pattern]
    A --> AT[Debugging]
    AT --> AU[Error]
    AT --> AV[Failure]
    AT --> AW[Fault]
    AT --> AX[Debugging Strategies]
    AX --> AY[Forwards Strategy]
    AX --> AZ[Backwards Strategy]
    A --> BA[Software Architecture]
    BA --> BB[Client-Server]
    BA --> BC[Pipe and Filter]
    BA --> BD[Model-View-Controller]
    BA --> BE[Peer-to-Peer]
    A --> BF[SOLID Principles]
    BF --> BG[Single Responsibility Principle]
    BF --> BH[Open/Closed Principle]
    BF --> BI[Liskov Substitution Principle]
    BF --> BJ[Interface Segregation Principle]
    BF --> BK[Dependency Inversion Principle]
```

This knowledge graph visually maps the relationships between the core topics in software engineering, providing a clear and easy-to-understand overview of the subject.
